slides.label: Scene
slides.text: Joe has been working with Claude for twenty minutes. Good progress. Then a thought occurs to him.

slides.label: Scene
slides.text: "What did you think about that approach we discussed yesterday? The one for the Henderson account?"

slides.label: The Response
slides.boxText: "I don't have any record of a previous conversation. Each conversation with me starts fresh."
slides.body: Joe stares at the screen. He's not angry — just lost. He was sure they'd talked about this. He starts typing the whole thing again from scratch.

slides.heading: What is this thing?
slides.body: Poor Joe. He's just discovered something that trips up nearly everyone who works with AI for the first time. But before we explain what happened, let's start with a bigger question.

slides.heading: Picture the future of AI. Which comes to mind?

options.title: Judgment Day
options.desc: The machines wake up. Military drones. Nuclear codes. We've all seen this movie.

options.title: The Quiet Fading
options.desc: Perfect digital companions. We stop connecting with each other. Humanity dies of stagnation.

options.title: Alien Intelligence
options.desc: Something fundamentally not like us. Something that speaks our language but does not share our nature.

slides.heading:
The alien intelligence
isn't coming.
It's already here.
slides.body: You're using it to write emails.

slides.heading:
We have no framework
for this.
slides.body: In the entire history of human experience, we have never encountered something that uses language fluently that wasn't either human or an animal we clearly recognized as an animal.

slides.heading:
This speaks
perfect English.
slides.body: It constructs complex arguments. It makes jokes. It asks clarifying questions. It says "I think" and "I believe" and "I understand." Every instinct you have says: person. And every one of those instincts is wrong.

slides.heading:
Oracles. Genies.
Demons. Fairies
who twist your words.
slides.body: For thousands of years, humans have told stories about entities that speak our language but don't share our nature. We thought these were fantasies. Turns out they were practice.

slides.label: What It Actually Is
slides.boxText: Not "just autocomplete." Not "a thinking machine." Both are so incomplete as to be misleading.
slides.body: "Just autocomplete" undersells it dramatically. "Thinking machine" oversells it. There's no evidence of inner experience or genuine understanding.

slides.heading:
Pattern completion
at massive scale.
slides.body: These systems processed essentially everything humans have written and made public. From this ocean of text, the system learned patterns — how words relate, how arguments are structured, how explanations work.

slides.heading:
Prediction,
not thinking.
slides.body: When you type a message, the system predicts what text should come next based on all those patterns. One piece at a time, constructing a response that fits the pattern of what a helpful answer would look like. The result can be brilliant. It can also be confidently, fluently wrong.

slides.heading:
Language means
another human mind.
slides.body: We are deeply wired for language. For hundreds of thousands of years, language meant a mind with experiences, memories, feelings. A persistent identity that would remember you tomorrow.

slides.label: Back to Joe
slides.text: Something in Joe's brain filed this under "person I worked with." He came back expecting memory. Continuity. A relationship. But there's no one there to remember. There never was.

slides.heading:
It sounds the same
whether it's right
or wrong.
slides.body: When a human isn't sure, you usually know. They hesitate, hedge, waver. AI doesn't work this way. When it generates a correct response and when it generates a complete fabrication, the tone is identical.

slides.heading:
The confidence
you're perceiving
isn't coming from the AI.
slides.body: It's coming from you. You're reading fluent text, and your brain interprets that as certainty. As knowing. This is why people include AI-generated statistics in proposals without checking them.

slides.label: The Context Window
slides.boxText: Every time you start a conversation with an AI, you're starting from zero.
slides.body: The system can only "see" what's in the current conversation. Imagine someone with perfect language abilities but absolutely no memory beyond this conversation. That's what Joe ran into.

slides.heading:
There isn't a single
"Claude" somewhere.
slides.body: Millions of conversations are happening right now. They share the same training but not experience. It's less like calling a person and more like consulting an infinitely patient encyclopedia. Each time you open it, it's a fresh copy.

slides.heading:
If you're feeling
slightly strange,
that's appropriate.
slides.body: Most people, when they really understand what AI is — and isn't — experience a wobble. A moment of "wait, what does this mean?" That disorientation you might be feeling right now? It has a name.

slides.heading:
Everyone goes
through this.
slides.body: Researchers, engineers, executives — the people who understand AI best all describe this moment. It's not a sign of weakness. It's a sign you're actually paying attention.

slides.heading:
The wobble passes.
And you're better
for it.
slides.body: On the other side of that disorientation is clarity. You'll use these tools more effectively, more honestly, and with fewer illusions. That's worth the momentary strangeness.

items.text: Don't expect memory. Each conversation starts fresh. If you need the AI to know something from yesterday, you have to tell it.
Don't trust confidence. Fluent text is not accurate text. Verify anything that matters.
Don't anthropomorphize. It's not "trying" to help you. When the output isn't what you want, the issue is usually the input.

Don't mistake politeness for relationship. AI won't be offended if you're blunt, and it won't remember your kindness tomorrow. But your tone shapes the output — bring energy and clarity, and the response reflects it.

slides.label: Back to Joe — A Few Days Later
slides.text: This time, Joe types something different. He provides context. The Henderson account. Three angles he'd considered. The one he preferred. The response is detailed, useful, building on what he gave it.

slides.heading:
The machine doesn't know
what you don't tell it.
slides.body: Joe still doesn't fully understand what he's working with. But he's learned one crucial lesson. It's a start.

slides.heading: Module 1 — Key Concepts
items: AI is alien intelligence — fluent in language, not like us
Our only frameworks come from mythology and folklore
Pattern completion at massive scale, not "thinking"
Fluency creates a false sense of understanding
Many instances, one training — no persistent self
The existential wobble is normal and healthy

quiz.question: When an AI gives a very confident-sounding answer, this means:
options: The AI is certain the information is correct
The AI has verified the information against reliable sources
Nothing about accuracy — fluent text sounds confident regardless of correctness
The AI has high "confidence scores" from its verification system

quiz.question: Joe asks Claude about a conversation they had yesterday. Claude says it doesn't recall. This is because:
options: Claude is experiencing a technical error
Each conversation starts fresh with no memory of previous sessions
Claude is programmed to deny previous interactions

quiz.question: Humanity's only cultural framework for "non-human intelligence that uses language" comes from:
options: Computer science textbooks and academic papers

quiz.question: AI is best understood as:
options: A thinking machine with genuine understanding
Fancy autocomplete, like your phone's keyboard
Pattern completion at massive scale — sophisticated but still prediction
A digital person with a different kind of consciousness
